title: How to Make Dairy‐Free Buttermilk Style Biscuits

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 450°F (232°C).
steps.description: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

steps.headline: Prepare the buttermilk.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of almond milk into a cup. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of lemon juice. Set the solution aside so that it can curdle. This is your vegan buttermilk. If you can't find any almond milk, try cashew or soy milk instead. If you can't find lemon juice, use 1 teaspoon of vinegar instead.

steps.headline: Whisk together the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, baking soda, and the salt. Stir everything together with a whisk until combined.

steps.headline: Cut the butter into the flour mixture.
steps.description: Use your fingers or a pastry blender to mix the butter into the flour. Keep doing this until the mixture is grainy, sort of like sand. Work quickly and don't let the butter melt.

steps.headline: Slowly add the vegan buttermilk.
steps.description: Make a well in the middle of your flour mixture first. Use a wooden spoon to stir in the vegan buttermilk ¼ cup (60 milliliters) at a time until everything is just combined. You want the mixture to be moist and a little sticky, so you may not end up using all of the buttermilk.

steps.headline: Work the dough 5 to 6 times into a lightly floured surface.
steps.description: Dust your counter or cutting board with flour. Turn the dough onto the floured surface, then sprinkle some more flour on top. Fold the dough in on itself 5 to 6 times. You want to just barely knead it.

steps.headline: Shape the dough into a 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) thick disk.
steps.description: Use your hands to do this, not a rolling pin. Don't worry if it's not perfect; you want to handle the dough as little as possible.

steps.headline: Cut biscuits out using a biscuit cutter.
steps.description: Push the biscuit cutter straight down into the dough, give it a twist, then pull it out. You should be able to cut out six biscuits. Squish the scraps into another disk, and cut 1 to 2 more biscuits out. If you don't have a biscuit cutter, you can use something else, as long as it has sharp edges.

steps.headline: Arrange the biscuits on a baking sheet in two rows.
steps.description: You want the biscuits to be just touching on the sheet. This will help them rise evenly while they bake. They will smoosh together when they rise, but you can easily pull them apart at the end.

steps.headline: Press the biscuits an brush them with melted butter.
steps.description: Use your thump to make a shallow dent in the center of each biscuit. This will help them rise evenly and flat. Melt some more vegan butter, and brush it over the top of each biscuit.

steps.headline: Bake the biscuits for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when they turn fluffy and golden-brown.

steps.headline: Serve the biscuits.
steps.description: If you have any leftover, let them cool all the way, then store them into a plastic zippered bag or airtight container.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 450°F (232°C).
steps.description: Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper.

steps.headline: Stir together the soy creamer and the apple cider vinegar.
steps.description: Pour the creamer into a bowl or cup. Add the apple cider vinegar, and give it a stir with a whisk. Set the solution aside so that it can curdle. This will be your vegan buttermilk. Can't find any soy creamer? Try cashew or almond instead. Don't have any vinegar? Use 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of lemon juice instead.

steps.headline: Sauté the sage and garlic.
steps.description: Melt the dairy-free butter in a small skillet. Let it get hot, then add the sage and garlic. Sauté them for 1 to 2 minutes, or until the garlic turn golden brown and fragrant.

steps.headline: Set the sautéed sage and garlic aside to cool.
steps.description: Use a spatula to scrape the sage and garlic onto a paper towel. Leave them there to cool off before continuing.

steps.headline: Combine the dry ingredients with the garlic and sage.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the sugar, baking powder, and salt. Once the garlic and sage have cooled off, add them into the mixing bowl as well. Stir everything together with a whisk until they evenly combined.

steps.headline: Pour in the vegan buttermilk gradually.
steps.description: Make a small well in the middle of your flour mixture. Slowly pour in the vegan buttermilk, ¼ cup (60 milliliters) at a time. Stir the mixture together as you pour with a wooden spoon. Be careful not to over-mix it, however.

steps.headline: Transfer the dough onto a floured surface.
steps.description: If you need to, sprinkle it with some flour, then lightly knead it 5 to 6 times. Once again, be careful not to over-knead the dough. If you do, it will become too warm and not rise properly.

steps.headline: Flatten the dough into a ¾-inch (1.91-centimeter) thick disk.
steps.description: Don't worry about it being perfect. You want to handle the dough as little as possible.

steps.headline: Cut the dough using a round biscuit cutter.
steps.description: Push the cutter straight into the dough, give it a slight twist, then pull it out. When you run out of space, smooth the scraps together, flatten the dough into another disk, and cut out more biscuits. You should be able to make 12 biscuits altogether. You can also use a round glass instead, as long as it has thin edges.

steps.headline: Place the biscuits into a baking sheet.
steps.description: Make sure that they are slightly touching. Once you have them arranged, lightly press the top of each one with your thumb to create a shallow indent. Both of these tricks will help the biscuits rise evenly while baking and prevent them from forming a domed top. If you want to, you can brush the tops of the biscuits with extra soy creamer. This will give them a nice shine on top.

steps.headline: Bake the biscuits for 12 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when they turn fluffy and golden brown.

steps.headline: Allow the biscuits to cool slightly before serving them.
steps.description: Gently pull them apart and serve them in a basket. If you have any left over, let them cool completely, then store them in a zippered bag or airtight container.

text: Making Basic Biscuits Preheat your oven to 450°F (232°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Prepare the buttermilk. Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of almond milk into a cup. Stir in 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of lemon juice. Set the solution aside so that it can curdle. This is your vegan buttermilk. If you can't find any almond milk, try cashew or soy milk instead. If you can't find lemon juice, use 1 teaspoon of vinegar instead. Whisk together the dry ingredients. Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, baking soda, and the salt. Stir everything together with a whisk until combined. Cut the butter into the flour mixture. Use your fingers or a pastry blender to mix the butter into the flour. Keep doing this until the mixture is grainy, sort of like sand. Work quickly and don't let the butter melt. Slowly add the vegan buttermilk. Make a well in the middle of your flour mixture first. Use a wooden spoon to stir in the vegan buttermilk ¼ cup (60 milliliters) at a time until everything is just combined. You want the mixture to be moist and a little sticky, so you may not end up using all of the buttermilk. Work the dough 5 to 6 times into a lightly floured surface. Dust your counter or cutting board with flour. Turn the dough onto the floured surface, then sprinkle some more flour on top. Fold the dough in on itself 5 to 6 times. You want to just barely knead it. Shape the dough into a 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) thick disk. Use your hands to do this, not a rolling pin. Don't worry if it's not perfect; you want to handle the dough as little as possible. Cut biscuits out using a biscuit cutter. Push the biscuit cutter straight down into the dough, give it a twist, then pull it out. You should be able to cut out six biscuits. Squish the scraps into another disk, and cut 1 to 2 more biscuits out. If you don't have a biscuit cutter, you can use something else, as long as it has sharp edges. Arrange the biscuits on a baking sheet in two rows. You want the biscuits to be just touching on the sheet. This will help them rise evenly while they bake. They will smoosh together when they rise, but you can easily pull them apart at the end. Press the biscuits an brush them with melted butter. Use your thump to make a shallow dent in the center of each biscuit. This will help them rise evenly and flat. Melt some more vegan butter, and brush it over the top of each biscuit. Bake the biscuits for 10 to 15 minutes. They are ready when they turn fluffy and golden-brown. Serve the biscuits. If you have any leftover, let them cool all the way, then store them into a plastic zippered bag or airtight container. Making Gourmet Buttermilk Biscuits Preheat your oven to 450°F (232°C). Cover a baking sheet with parchment paper. Stir together the soy creamer and the apple cider vinegar. Pour the creamer into a bowl or cup. Add the apple cider vinegar, and give it a stir with a whisk. Set the solution aside so that it can curdle. This will be your vegan buttermilk. Can't find any soy creamer? Try cashew or almond instead. Don't have any vinegar? Use 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) of lemon juice instead. Sauté the sage and garlic. Melt the dairy-free butter in a small skillet. Let it get hot, then add the sage and garlic. Sauté them for 1 to 2 minutes, or until the garlic turn golden brown and fragrant. Set the sautéed sage and garlic aside to cool. Use a spatula to scrape the sage and garlic onto a paper towel. Leave them there to cool off before continuing. Combine the dry ingredients with the garlic and sage. Pour the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add the sugar, baking powder, and salt. Once the garlic and sage have cooled off, add them into the mixing bowl as well. Stir everything together with a whisk until they evenly combined. Pour in the vegan buttermilk gradually. Make a small well in the middle of your flour mixture. Slowly pour in the vegan buttermilk, ¼ cup (60 milliliters) at a time. Stir the mixture together as you pour with a wooden spoon. Be careful not to over-mix it, however. Transfer the dough onto a floured surface. If you need to, sprinkle it with some flour, then lightly knead it 5 to 6 times. Once again, be careful not to over-knead the dough. If you do, it will become too warm and not rise properly. Flatten the dough into a ¾-inch (1.91-centimeter) thick disk. Don't worry about it being perfect. You want to handle the dough as little as possible. Cut the dough using a round biscuit cutter. Push the cutter straight into the dough, give it a slight twist, then pull it out. When you run out of space, smooth the scraps together, flatten the dough into another disk, and cut out more biscuits. You should be able to make 12 biscuits altogether. You can also use a round glass instead, as long as it has thin edges. Place the biscuits into a baking sheet. Make sure that they are slightly touching. Once you have them arranged, lightly press the top of each one with your thumb to create a shallow indent. Both of these tricks will help the biscuits rise evenly while baking and prevent them from forming a domed top. If you want to, you can brush the tops of the biscuits with extra soy creamer. This will give them a nice shine on top. Bake the biscuits for 12 to 15 minutes. They are ready when they turn fluffy and golden brown. Allow the biscuits to cool slightly before serving them. Gently pull them apart and serve them in a basket. If you have any left over, let them cool completely, then store them in a zippered bag or airtight container.
